Adjective: in good health especially after having suffered illness or injury
wise or advantageous and hence advisable
Adverb: `good' is a nonstandard dialectal variant for `well'
thoroughly or completely; fully; often used as a combining form
indicating high probability; in all likelihood
(used for emphasis or as an intensifie)
to a suitable or appropriate extent or degree
to a great extent or degree
with great or especially intimate knowledge
with skill or in a pleasing manner
in a manner affording benefit or advantage
without unusual distress or resentment; with good humor
Noun: a deep hole or shaft dug or drilled to obtain water or oil or gas or brine
a cavity or vessel used to contain liquid
an open shaft through the floors of a building (as for a stairwa)
an enclosed compartment in a ship or plane for holding something as e.g. fish or a plane's landing gear or for protecting something as e.g. a ship's pumps
Verb: come up, as of a liquid
